QuoteText: From a strictly 'argument' point of view, emotion shouldn't enter the picture. If pro-lifers/anti-abortionists looked at the issue dispassionately and rationally (difficult, I know), then they may well end up with a different viewpoint. How do we take the emotion out of argument?
ResponseText: That's the very challenge that keeps me engaged in these debates. I don't get the emotions anymore. I used to feel the panic that "babies are being killed and I have to do something to save them" until I realized that show of emotion just turned people away and I gained nothing by it. I still feel guilt when a day goes by and I didn't post something or try to reach someone somehow to debate the issue. But it's an emotion that I live with by knowing that I'm doing the best I can. Still, I have seen so many of the pictures, read so many rants and debates, etc... that I now see so many more of the aspects to the issue that thosed mired down in their emotions will often miss. Like the way elective abortion is used by predatory type men to victimize women. (Nicole Brown Simpson, Bonnie Blakely, refused to abort their babies and were subsequently murdered) So, when you say you would like to find a way to take the emotionalism out of it? Me too!

ResponseText: "...aging begins at the time of conception . In fact, we age more during those nine months of gestation than at any other time during our entire life after we leave our mothers womb ." -- The Lee Benner Institute "Using the rate of change definition of aging, the rate of aging in mammals is most rapid during the fetal period when organisms develop from a single cell at conception to a multicellular organism containing trillions of cells at birth."-- University of Wisconsin "As soon as engine of life switches on at conception, the damage associated with aging begins to accumulate. It is inevitable, it is cumulative, and, at this point, it cannot be stopped or reversed." --Jay Olshansky is a professor of public health at the University of Illinois at Chicago Tell me something, Colonel D. Ingus,... How can a human being's aging begin at conception; but their life does not? Please provide some scientific evidence to support your claims.
